repository.corpname: NYU Abu Dhabi, Archives and Special Collections

did.unittitle: NYU Abu Dhabi Institute: Public Program Materials

physdesc.extent: in 2 legal size document boxes; 1 OS Flat File; 3 [16x20] OS boxes of 343 DVDs; 159 USB flash drives

did.abstract: The collection "Records of the NYU Abu Dhabi Institute: Public Program Materials" documents over ten years' worth of events that took place at the Institute from 2007 through 2020, with the majority of the contents covering the years 2008 through 2015. This body of material from the Institute's first decade is relevant to anyone researching the early years of NYU Abu Dhabi as a way to understand the University's regional and global role in advancing research and scholarship, and exchanging knowledge collaboratively with the wider public.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The initial three increments of this collection were transferred to the University Archives in March 2019, with further accretions expected.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: RG 24-1 is comprised of four open series. 1. Calendars, Promotional Materials, and Program Brochures, 2008-2018. 2. Photographic Materials: Prints and Contact Sheets [ca. 2008-2013]. 3. NYUAD Institute Yearbooks, 2008-2019. 4. Audiovisual event and public program files, 2007-2015. Materials are arranged chronologically in each series by date of event.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: New York University, in developing a new "Global Network" of degree granting campuses and academic centers across six continents (NYU New York, NYU Abu Dhabi, and NYU Shanghai), established the NYU Abu Dhabi Institute in 2008, two years prior to the Abu Dhabi campus opening its doors to its first class of students and faculty. The Institute was the first "on-the-ground" operation of the University in the UAE. As a research outreach and sponsorship component, it was established to create and support innovative research programs, organize public discussions with experts from around the world, and invite participation not only from and for the NYU network constituency but also from and for local, regional, and national communities.

The Institute's inaugural program in October 2008, "On the Art of the Novel," featured renowned Lebanese novelist Elias Khoury. Its "first collaboration" came during the November 2008 program "Stephen Hawking's 'A Briefer History of Time'," featuring the Arabic translation of that book by Kalima, the translation initiative launched by Abu Dhabi Authority for Culture and Heritage (ADACH). In December of 2008, "Neurolinguistics and Imaging: Progress and Prospects" was the first multi-day program that the NYU Abu Dhabi Institute sponsored. Early events took place at the Al Mamoura Auditorium in Abu Dhabi.

NYU Abu Dhabi Institute programming was early-on a joint effort between faculty and administration in Abu Dhabi, and faculty and administrative leadership in New York. The Institute created an Advisory Committee that also first convened in Decmeber 2008, and in May of 2009, the NYUAD offices at 19 Washington Square North sponsored the first New York-hosted Institute event, a lecture titled "Building Big: A Critical Examination of the Planning of Mega Urban Transportation." The Institute continues to organize programs in both Abu Dhabi and New York. When the NYU Abu Dhabi downtown campus was built and finally available as a venue for programs, the Institute hosted its first on-campus lecture there in December 2009, "The Predictioneer's Game," a talk about game theory with NYU Professor Bruce Bueno de Mesquita. Student-centered Institute programming was introduced in 2011 with the "Hackathon for Social Good in the Arab World."

Today, the NYUAD Institute continues to sponsor and support multi-day conferences, workshops and seminars relevant to the NYUAD curriculum and areas of research, across a range of subjects from falconry to poetry to genomics to youth unemployment crises. The Institute has become an important asset of the university that seeks to deepen understanding of the world, generate important new knowledge, and facilitate breakthrough discoveries in science and technology.
References and for further information: "10 Years: Celebrating the NYU Abu Dhabi Institute"

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Lauren Kata and Kainaath Ahmad Shah Mumtaz, with assistance from Ian Bryce Hoyt and Arnav Vinay Kochar, 2019-2021.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Users and researchers may find additional resources on the NYU Abu Dhabi Institue YouTube Channel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection "Records of the NYU Abu Dhabi Institute: Public Program Materials" documents over ten years' worth of events that took place at the Institute from 2007 through 2020, with the majority of the contents covering the years 2008 through 2015. This body of material from the Institute's first decade will be of interest to anyone researching the early years of NYU Abu Dhabi as a way to understand the University's regional and global role in advancing research and scholarship, and exchanging knowledge collaboratively with the wider public.

Materials include printed calendars; promotional cards, flyers, and brochures; a small collection of printed photographic materials; published "Year in Review" yearbooks; and audiovisual files (photos, videos, slide presentations) from over 300 events sponsored by the Institute from 2007-2015.
The series "Calendars, Promotional Materials, and Program Brochures" is a collection of printed materials that were displayed, distributed and mailed as invitations, covering the years 2008-2014.

The small series "Photographic Materials" separates out some of the printed photographs and contact sheets from early events (although, users should note that the majority of event photos have been preserved as part of the audiovisual series).
A full set of published yearbooks, the Institute's annually published "Year in Review," offers highlights and overviews of each year's programming.

Finally, this collection's audiovisual series offers not only a detailed inventory of what the collection contains as far as photographed and video-recorded events, but also information about associated program officers and speakers, as well as external links to online published clips and videos for selected events, hosted on the Institute's YouTube channel.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The use of any materials beyond what is commonly understood as "fair use" would require permission of the presumptive copyright holder(s).

did.unittitle: Calendars, Promotional Materials and Program Brochures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A collection of printed materials that were displayed, distributed and mailed as invitations, covering the years 2008-2014.

did.unittitle: Photographic Materials: Photo prints and Contact Sheets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a small series that separates out some of the printed photographs and contact sheets from early events that were transferred with records to the University Archives (users should note that the majority of event photos are digital, and have been preserved as part of the Audiovisual Event Files series).

did.unittitle: Photo Contact Sheets: Search for Social Entrepreneurship
Photo Contact Sheets: Education, Media, and Human Development

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The NYUAD Institute publishes an annual "Year in Review," a yearbook highlighting major events throughout the year. This series includes selected print copies of the publication, as well as E-book versions.

Note: copies of the NYUAD Institute Year in Review are also in the NYUAD Publications and Ephemera Collection (AD-RG-2), as well as the Records of the Office of Public Affairs: Publications (AD-RG-9).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: NYU Abu Dhabi Institute staff arranged for the photography and video recording of most Institute events. Many of the recordings have been curated and shared on the Institute's YouTube Channel. Records in this series constitute the full packaged files from various lectures, workshops and conferences, and are organized by date of event. Records are primarily audiovisual, and include digital photos, video footage, and in some cases, copies of slide presentations from events 2008 - 2015. Archivists continue to partner with NYUAD Institute staff for the ongoing transfer of inactive materials.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual materials have been minimally processed. The container list below provides a basic inventory of contents. Files are viewable onsite by appointment.
